items.title: backward forward patch buttons
items.body: Sorry, wrong group

items.title: Proposal: add simple ADSR editor
items.body:
The current envelope generator is pretty intimidating for first time users so I propose that we add an option to use a simple ADSR envelope generator 

this would just change how it is displayed.

1. the attack knob will just affect EG rate 1
2. the decay knob will just affect EG rate 3
3. the sustain knob will just affect EG level 3
4. the release knob will just affect EG rate 4

one issue is what to do when switching from the advanced EG to the simple EG.
2 potential options are: 

1. pretend like nothing happened and just keep the knob positions even if the simple adsr editor can't change them.
2. give you a warning that you need to confirm then set the incompatible knobs to the default value (potentially saving them for if you revert back to the advanced EG)

I would be happy to implement everything.

items.title: added octave up and down buttons
items.body:
I added octave shift buttons and very basic documentation for the feature. 
This currently has an issue where if press one of the octave buttons while holding notes it can cause them to get stuck. but this is also an issue in Surge-XT and LMMS iirc.

Also at some point I hope to add a panic button that will clear all audio output and active notes.

items.title: VST3: program change message does not notify host about parameter changes
items.body:
When I change the VST3 program parameter, e.g. in the generic UI of Reaper or with the `[program(` message in the `[vstplugin~]` Pd external, Dexed does not tell which parameters have changed. Other VST3 plugins would call the `restartComponent` method with the `kParamValuesChanged` flag, so that the host can update its own parameter representation.

Tested with Dexed 0.9.6 (VST3) on Windows 10.

items.title: Automated parameters not updated in UI (VST3)
items.body:
The VST3 version of Dexed does not update parameters in the UI when I try to automate them programatically, e.g. with automation curves in Reaper or with messages in Pure Data (see https://git.iem.at/pd/vstplugin). The corresponding UI elements just don't move. Curiously, a few parameters do work, e.g. `Resonance`, `Cutoff`, `OP4 L SCALE DEPTH` or `OP4 BREAK POINT`.

Tested with Dexed 0.9.6 (VST3) on Windows 10.

items.title: Persist more Dexed parameters in per-instance state
items.body:
Trying to recreate TX816-style performances by combining multiple Dexed instances in the DAW, I am running into the issue that some of these parameters seemingly are only persisted across all instances of Dexed (in `C:\Users\%USERNAME%\AppData\Roaming\DigitalSuburban\Dexed\Dexed.xml`), whereas the TX816 requires some of these parameters to be different across the 8 tone generators:

```
  <VALUE name="normalizeDxVelocity" val="0"/>
  <VALUE name="pitchRange" val="0"/>
  <VALUE name="pitchRangeUp" val="0"/>
  <VALUE name="pitchRangeDn" val="1"/>
  <VALUE name="pitchStep" val="0"/>
  <VALUE name="sysexIn" val=""/>
  <VALUE name="sysexOut" val=""/>
  <VALUE name="sysexChl" val="0"/>
  <VALUE name="showKeyboard" val="1"/>
  <VALUE name="wheelMod" val="0 0 0 0"/>
  <VALUE name="footMod" val="0 0 0 0"/>
  <VALUE name="breathMod" val="0 0 0 0"/>
  <VALUE name="aftertouchMod" val="0 0 0 0"/>
  <VALUE name="engineType" val="1"/>
  <VALUE name="dpiScaleFactor" val="1.0"/>
```

Specifically:
* pitchRangeUp
* pitchRangeDn
* pitchStep
* wheelMod _(is already persisted per instance via `PluginData.cpp`)_
* footMod _(is already persisted per instance via `PluginData.cpp`)_
* breathMod _(is already persisted per instance via `PluginData.cpp`)_
* aftertouchMod _(is already persisted per instance via `PluginData.cpp`)_

Likely the missing ones would need to be added to `DexedAudioProcessor::getStateInformation()` before https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/blob/b6cf2e9190e216387ad96f977284ebbef765b447/Source/PluginData.cpp#L331 for saving the per-instance state,

and to `DexedAudioProcessor::setStateInformation()` https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/blob/b6cf2e9190e216387ad96f977284ebbef765b447/Source/PluginData.cpp#L411 for applying the per-instance state.

items.title: Load voice data from the MIDI track in a DAW
items.body:
User story: As a user, I would like to put voice data into my MIDI track that is being played by Dexed in a DAW (the one that contains the notes to be played). When playing MIDI from the track, the voice data from the sysex should be loaded into the Dexed VST. My use case i that I would like to script loading voice data into Dexed inside Reaper.

Currently it seems that Dexed only accepts sysex over the MIDI device set under PARM as "MIDI In".

It would be nice if it would also accept sysex coming in from the MIDI track that is being played. Just like it plays MIDI notes, it should also load MIDI sysex. This way, MIDI notes and MIDI sysex could be saved together on the same track in the DAW. This would allow to automate (by scripting the DAW) the setup of multiple layers (tracks) in TX816 style.

![image](https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/assets/2480569/6a882951-76d4-4e92-9ec0-f0ad4e4360e6)

In the picture, each of the tracks TG1...TG8 contains a sysex ("SYX") with the voice data that should be played by the Dexed instance that is on the respective track.

More information:
https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/discussions/352

items.title: Expose .syx files as JSON or vstpreset?
items.body:
There are many .syx files floating around, but the file format is hard to understand. It would be amazing if the presets were human-readable.

There is a lot of work on inverse synthesis (pick paramaters given a sound) using Dexed, and it would be amazing to be able to easily have a corpus of *good* presets. However, I am tearing my hair out trying to parse the .syx file format. And generating random patches isn't cool.

I would love a syx_to_json script, that would be amazing.

Hello,

When using the VST3 version of Dexed in Qtractor, the plugin settings are not restored if the session is closed and reopened.

The author also noted that the bug is not present in the VST2 version.

Thank you for your help—Dexed is an awesome instrument.

items.title: SIMD-vectorize operators using libhwy
items.body:
This is an offshoot from some experimentation I was doing using dexed and I wasn't really planning on developing further, but in case it's useful to anyone I'll present it here.

This uses google's [highway library](https://github.com/google/highway) to add SIMD versions of the most expensive parts of the synthesis. My crude testing suggests modest speed improvements of 10-20% for SSE2 to AVX2, but on an AVX512 machine this easily doubles speed for me. An ARM NEON system showed an embarrassing 4% acceleration.

Dexed doesn't have a test suite, but comparing the results against the existing scalar implementation showed a maximum relative error of ~0.003 between the two, which will be attributable to a different order of operations in some places.

I don't know whether you'd ever actually want to make dexed depend on libhwy, but this would probably take a bit more polish if you ever wanted to actually merge it - I've tested it only on a limited variety of machines/architectures, haven't included options to disable vectorization support, have only configured libhwy for single-dispatch (no single-binary, dynamic cpu-extension-detecting, but I don't imagine it would be too hard to set that up).

The feedback-based operator loops are way too hard to vectorize, so they are left alone.

items.title: Loading patches over sysex is corrupted about 35% of the time, 0.9.6 only
items.body:
I maintain a large patch editor toolkit, Edisyn, which has a DX7 editor. Up until 0.9.4 (on Intel or M1) Dexed worked perfectly with sysex sent it via Edisyn over a Mac MIDI Loopback. I upgraded to 0.9.6, which likely is running M1 native, and about 35% of the time sysex patches sent it will arrive corrupted, producing some nasty BZZZZ sound rather than the actual patch. If you resend the patch once or twice, Dexed recognizes it and plays it properly. Downgrading back to 0.9.4 and Dexed works flawlessly again.

I am pretty certain that this bug is not Edisyn: the patch sysex appears correct. I also know that it is not due to timing issues (such as pausing a long time after a patch is dumped before playing a note, etc.). It appears to be a Dexed error. I do not know if this bug is due to 0.9.6 or due to the change in Dexed from running Intel (or on Rosetta) vs. running natively on the M1. But it is definitely a showstopper for patch editors using Dexed.

items.title: MacOS release installer mpkg throws critical errors in Suspicious Package
items.body:
[ EDIT: i should probably mention my environment: 
mac mini m2 pro running ventura v13.3 ]

first off thank you so much for archiving and maintaining this project. this is one of my favorite vst synths and i was pretty bummed when i discovered it had gone cold for a while. 

i tried running the latest macos installer (dexed-0.9.6-macos), pulled from the Dexed site and the releases page (they appear to be mirrors). 

Suspicious Package throws 2 critical issues

	1. can't get list of files to be installed, since the component package "Standalone.pkg" is missing or corrupted

	2. Can't analyze payload, since the component package "Standalone.pkg" is missing or corrupted

both have sub flags of 

	- the file "Info.plist" couldn't be opened
	- the operation couldn't be completed. Not a directory.

 i inspected the mpkg contents and found the "distribution.dist" script file in ./Contents/

on line 32:
     <pkg-ref id="com.digitalsuburban.DexedStandalone" version="0.9.6" installKBytes="7334">file:./Contents/Packages/Standalone.pkg</pkg-ref>

additionally
./Contents/Packages contains the following 

      	AU.pkg
      	Standalone.pkg
      	VST3.pkg

 i am not familiar enough with metapackages to know if it's a pathing issue, or if it is somehow corrupted/damaged.

 i was able to extract and export the vst3 and app files manually without launcing the respective pkg files, and can confirm that the standalone seems to be working fine. 

![Screenshot 2023-05-11 at 12 40 25 PM](https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/assets/67727284/5d72f673-b591-4d48-8860-21b7002ca989)

items.title: CLAP plugin failed to scan on REAPER with Apple Silicon CPU
items.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Download Dexed 0.9.7 Nightly.
2. `xattr -rd com.apple.quarantine Dexed_artefacts` to make sure macOS doesn’t enforce binary signature.
3. Copy `Dexed_artefacts/Debug/CLAP/Dexed.clap` to `~/Library/Audio/Plug-Ins/CLAP/`.
4. Start REAPER.
5. Choose Options → Settings → Plug-ins → LV2/CLAP → CLAP plug-in settings → Re-scan/Info.
6. Choose “Clear cache and re-scan CLAP paths for all plug-ins”.

What to expect:
* Dexed is successfully added to REPAER.

What I observed:
* REAPER lists Dexed as “Plug-ins that failed to scan”.

Additional info:
* Dexed version: 0.9.7 Nightly (2022-07-13)
* REAPER version: v6.78/macOS-arm64 (2023-03-14)
* OS version: macOS Ventura 13.3.1
* CPU Chip: Apple M1 Max

items.title: License should be LGPL instead of GPL
items.body: Because of its nature as a plugin which counts as a library, there are projects that will want to use dexed as part of their DX7-ish emulation, but differences in licenses would make it impossible to include dexed right away, because the said projects are licensed under licenses that don't allow GPLv3 software to be included. Permissive licenses like MIT and the first few BSDs allow inclusion in projects of any license. The LGPL does the same thing, but it's perfectly copyleft like regular GPL and unlike the permissive licenses.

items.title: DX7 OUT MIDI CH possibly ignored from CART view?
items.body:
Attached is a screengrab from MIDIOx showing the SysEx voice dump when DX7 Channel = 2.  The first is the dump from the main editor window for right click->send current program to DX7.  The second is the dump from the CART window for right click->send program to DX7.

The third byte (status | device ID) is 0x01 for the first but 0x00 for the second.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/68612569/206928236-77912c19-bba1-48de-8815-9393ebe0916a.png)

I believe the code for sending the Program data here https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/blob/master/Source/CartManager.cpp#L305
should be adding in the MIDI channel to the SysEx message, in the same way it is done here: https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/blob/master/Source/PluginData.cpp#L269

Kevin

items.title: Dexed checkboxes are incorrectly represented as radio buttons
items.body:
Dexed has green radio buttons, rather than checkboxes, for its "Active output channels", "Active Input channels", and "Active MIDI inputs" selectors, even though they act like checkboxes. This caused a lot of grief for me as I selected a new Active MIDI input, unaware that the other input had not been deselected as would be expected in a normal radio button.  Please change these to checkboxes.

While we're at it, why are there more than one active MIDI Inputs?  Dexed still doesn't support sysex patch requests.

While we're at it, why is the MIDI Output a popup menu but the other choosers are checkboxes masquerading as radio buttons?

items.title: Dexed is incorrectly treating its MIDI OUT as a MIDI THRU
items.body:
All MIDI data passed into Dexed via its MIDI IN are being improperly routed to MIDI OUT.   This causes no end of consternation for patch editors working with Dexed.

(Macbook M1, 12.6 Monterey, recent copy of Dexed, but Dexed has no version information).

items.title: Complete instrument package and Midi instructions are supported.

Will the future support:
1.high fidelity emulation, with choice of compromise level (good fidelity/fast, excellent fidelity/slow)
2.synthesis of melodic and percussive instruments
3.extensible polyphony
4.bundled collection of instruments
5.support for dynamic parameterization and automation
6.rigorous implementation of the MIDI standard
7.multi-channel operation with General MIDI compatibility

items.title: Fix Linux build in pipeline
items.body:
- Add libjack-jackd2-dev to apt install
- Add an optout to cmake (default to 0 since dexed is gpl3)

items.title: Fix a Windows CLAP linker error
items.body:
Since JUCE and CLAP were included in CMake *before* the MSVC
Runtime was picked, the CLAP CMake picked the system default which
in some build configurations would lead to a conflict at link time.

Fix this by simply moving the include of JUCE and JUCE CLap Extensions
to after the set up of architecture, runtime, etc...

items.title: Clap Implementation for DEXED
items.body:
This diff adds the necessary hooks to allow Dexed to
build as a CLAP 1.0.0 plugin. More information on the
new CLAP plugin format is at https://github.com/free-audio/clap

Due to Dexed using a slightly older scaling API, this also disables
the 1.5x high resolution monitor scaling feature in plugins just
for CLAP plugins only

items.title: Yamaha DX7IIFD w/ E! Grey Matter sysex loads as corrupted data in Dexed?
items.body:
I tried to backup some files from my Yamaha DX7IIFD with MIDI-OX which I used to use all the time years ago. When I loaded the sysex into Dexed, it just shows up as completely corrupted data. When I send the sysex back to the DX7IIFD, it works perfectly fine. Here is [a test file](https://mega.nz/file/UHBTmQ7S#HnVqBKaFYIGYdR6hQmkM4q-_ulpRUqOoh8e8W8AHU3A) [should be MinoruMukaiya(KV03B).syx]

I'm assuming this problem might be because of the E! Grey Matter board installed on the hardware?

items.title: Flush denormals
items.body:
Dexed shows an increase in cpu usage on note off
calculating tiny numbers way below audible range.
This change sets these small numbers to zero.

should also help with https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed/issues/322#issuecomment-1097108930

items.title: Simple ratio locking?
items.body:
Something Digitones do that is very helpful is lock ratios to simple ratios. These are mostly single-digit ratios (1:2, 2:3, 3:5 etc) but the integer relationship puts modulators close to something musical. So it's much easier to turn the knobs and avoid a lot of garbage noise that FM is prone to. I've seen people now mention wanting to know how to do FM synthesis so I recommended Dexed but had to explain this method to them.

Having an option to enable the ratio locking in some way would make Dexed more approachable.

```
/wrkdirs/usr/ports/audio/dexed/work/dexed-0.9.6-16-g1df9a58/Source/PluginData.cpp:113:13: error: taking the absolute value of unsigned type 'char' has no effect [-Werror,-Wabsolute-value]
    value = abs(value);
            ^
/wrkdirs/usr/ports/audio/dexed/work/dexed-0.9.6-16-g1df9a58/Source/PluginData.cpp:113:13: note: remove the call to 'abs' since unsigned values cannot be negative
    value = abs(value);
            ^~~
/wrkdirs/usr/ports/audio/dexed/work/dexed-0.9.6-16-g1df9a58/Source/PluginData.cpp:312:29: error: result of comparison of constant -1 with expression of type 'char' is always true [-Werror,-Wtautological-constant-out-of-range-compare]
    return clipboardContent != -1;
           ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ^  ~~
2 errors generated.
```

Version: 0.9.6-16-g1df9a58
clang-13

items.title: Fix parameter remote control in Bitwig by using name as parameter ID
items.body:
Bitwig Studio's remote control of Dexed was broken (as of version 4.2.2) such that Dexed parameters could be mapped to remote controls, but changing those remotes would not affect change in Dexed. This was apparently caused by parameter ID strings clashing with the default implementation which converts index int to String. Using the unique parameter name as the ID instead resolved the problem. Before fix:
Plugin misbehaving output from Bitwig 
[2022-04-17 14:36:02.250 float-main-app error] Plugin misbehaving Dexed: Listed an automatable parameter as a MIDI parameter: ParamID = 1567 index = 10
[2022-04-17 14:36:02.251 float-main-app error] Plugin misbehaving Dexed: Multiple definitions of parameters with the same parameter id were found for the following parameter ids: 
After fix: No "Plugin misbehaving" output from Bitwig, and remote controls work.

items.title: Respect MIDI channel on control change mappings
items.body: This change makes it possible to map the entire instrument with CC's from different channels (e.g. Channel 1 for Operator 1, Channel 2 for Operator 2, etc.). Without channel discrimination in the dexed mappings, there aren't enough CC #'s to go around. As a simple and efficient approach, the channel and CC share an int value (CC on bits 0-7, channel on bits 8-15).

items.title: Please don't depend on ALSA on FreeBSD
items.body:
ALSA is a linux technology and isn't well supported on FreeBSD,

Please use OSS or Jack instead on FreeBSD.

to enable the FreeBSD port

- don't turn on `-Werror` just yet

Closes #322
Closes #340
Closes #343

items.title: How to disable VST?
items.body:
Build on FreeBSD fails for me with:
> #error To build JUCE VST3 plug-ins on BSD you must use an external BSD-compatible VST3 SDK with JUCE_CUSTOM_VST3_SDK=1

How to disable VST for now?

For reference, the [Surge XT](https://github.com/surge-synthesizer/surge) project had the same issue but building with ```-DJUCE_PLUGINHOST_VST3=OFF -DJUCE_PLUGINHOST_VST=OFF``` helped. This doesn't help for ```dexed```.

items.title: Don't use `-Werror` just yet
items.body: It is too early in the process for "warnings are errors"

items.title: Respect MIDI channel on control change mappings
items.body: This change makes it possible to map the entire instrument with CC's from different channels (e.g. Channel 1 for Operator 1, Channel 2 for Operator 2, etc.). Without channel discrimination in the dexed mappings, there aren't enough CC #'s to go around.

items.title: Use buses API for channel configuration
items.body:
Without configuration the plugin would expose a multitude of input and output channels, at least when used
in Carla. The projucer's pluginChannelConfigs option cannot be carried over to the cmake build system
so, following [1], channel configuration is done using the buses API .

[1] https://github.com/juce-framework/JUCE/blob/master/docs/CMake%20API.md

items.title: More CMake changes and less warnings
items.body:
- remove `juce_recommended_warning_flags`
  This otherwise builds with `-Wall -Wextra` which shows a lot of less- or unimportant
  warnings with the important ones lost inbetween, plus you can not supress warnings.
- move recommended lto and config flags to public as per juce recomendation
- fix a few warnings
- update tuningui submodule

In total this brings the 2k+ displayed warnings down to managable 28
which are a few deprecated-declarations and two unused values.

- add configurable option to add or supress warnings to CMakeLists.txt
  turned on as an example for linux, which in this example supresses the remaining warnings
  while newly introduced warnings will error.

items.title: JUCE as a submodule
items.body:
The cmake addition is great (thanks @showlabor)!
I'd like to suggest making JUCE a submodule though.

The way it is included via CPM now means it downloads around 250Mb
every time a new build folder is created or JUCE gets updated.
Adding it as a submodule with depth1 you end up with aprox 60Mb once,
updates are incremental and it's independent from the build folder.

This will also speed up potential pipeline builds.

items.title: Initial cmake support
items.body:
This adds support for the cmake build system. I don't regard it as complete ny any means. It is very basic and has only been tested on Debian. It doesn't conflict, though, with the projucer based build system. Not a single existing file had to be changed. So this might serve as a first step towards a proper transistion to cmake.

Please, see README_cmake.md for the details.

items.title: Adjust feedback for algorithm 32 in Mk I engine
items.body:
Pushing the feedback value up to 7 in algorithm 32 results in digital noise, see issue asb2m10#146.
That's not how the original DX7 behaves.
This patch tries to fix this issue by scaling the feedback value for algorithm 32. It sounds
much closer to the (at least my) DX7 Mk I and doesn't produce the digital noise any more.

In direct comparison, at feedback value 7 it sounds a bit brighter than my original DX7.
I tried different scalings (e.g. feedback_shift+3) which sounded a bit too muffled.
So overall (feedback_shift+2) sounds closest to my DX7.

This might need further investigaion but for now I think that this scaling is much better than
the digital noise currently produced.

items.title: macOS’ Dexed.app has unchanging version numbers
items.body:
To accurately display version information, macOS apps need to have the `CFBundleVersion` and `CFBundleShortVersionString` tags in `Info.plist`.

In `Dexed.app` they’re at a fixed `1.0.0` instead of the release number. If numbers are not set during the build process, they can be changed after it’s done by directly editing the `Info.plist`:

```bash
# Change these values
app_path='/PATH/TO/APP/HERE'
app_version='VERSION NUMBER HERE'

# Keep these as they are
/usr/libexec/PlistBuddy -c "Set :CFBundleVersion string ${app_version}" "${app_path}/Contents/Info.plist"
/usr/libexec/PlistBuddy -c "Set :CFBundleShortVersionString string ${app_version}" "${app_path}/Contents/Info.plist"
```

That would use the same version number for both fields. Technically they should be different, but even having both the same would be a major improvement.

Accurate versions numbers are important for macOS to know which app to open in ambiguous situations; for users (who expect to see them in the Finder); and for accurate interoperability with other apps.

items.title: Improve scaling for HighDPI displays
items.body: Currently semi-manual scaling applies only to the main window (excluding elements in its title bar).  In particular, the window where you can manually override the scaling factor is itself not scaled.  Also, although the 150% scaling is a slight improvement, it's not enough for all High-DPI displays.  This change switches to fully-automatic scaling for the full application, based on the DPI returned for the main display.  It makes all the text of the whole application readable for the first time on my laptop display (where I needed 220% scaling).

items.title: Reface DX mode
items.body:
Just a feature request for a Reface DX mode somewhere down the line, since I hear there's an OPL mode.

The Reface DX is a stand-alone 4-op FM synthesizer available for like $300, which makes it plenty accessible for people looking to get into FM synthesis.  It has an online library on Soundmondo, which automatically connects to a MIDI device to program the Reface DX; Dexed could also act as a MIDI device and expose itself as a Reface DX for this purpose.

This would thus be a low-budget path for people to use e.g. OpenMPT (which still only supports VST2, though) with instruments compatible with a portable hardware synthesizer keyboard.

items.title: Stand-alone program provide harmonic spectrum
items.body: It would be useful if the stand-alone program could visualize the harmonic spectrum, to make it somewhat easier to work out what the patch is doing and make the appropriate adjustments.

items.title: Provided Linux build procedure does not work on non-x86 architectures
items.body:
Trying to build Dexed according to the provided instructions does not work on ARM, because the `Projucer` binary downloaded by `get-juce.sh` is for x86_64, and cannot be run by `projuce.sh`:
```
Generating build for VST3
./scripts/projuce.sh: line 16: assets/JUCE/Projucer: cannot execute binary file: Exec format error
```

Fortunately, it is still possible to build Projucer from source, and I was able to get Dexed built and working by replacing ./assets/JUCE/Projucer with the recompiled binary. So for the complete build process:
```
https://github.com/asb2m10/dexed
cd dexed
git submodule update --init --recursive
./scripts/get_juce.sh

cd ..
git clone https://github.com/juce-framework/JUCE
cd JUCE
cmake . -B cmake-build -DJUCE_BUILD_EXTRAS=ON  # takes a long time
cmake --build cmake-build --target Projucer    # takes a very long time
cp cmake-build/extras/Projucer/Projucer_artefacts/Projucer ../dexed/assets/JUCE/Projucer   # overwrites x86 Projucer binary

cd ..
cd dexed
./scripts/projuce.sh  # should actually work now
./scripts/build-lin.sh
```
And if all goes well, a working binary should be dropped in `Builds/Linux/build/Dexed`.

It seems that nothing about support for Linux on ARM here is actually broken, and it's just the build system not making any attempt to detect or work with non-x86 architectures. Once I'd stumbled my way into this solution, I was able to compile a working binary of Dexed on my Pinebook Pro running Manjaro, and it works excellently connected to my keyboard via USB with Pipewire (emulating JACK) as the audio backend. Since there are a lot of ARM devices like this with favorable characteristics for audio work - especially the Raspberry Pi series, which see a lot of artistic use - I think it would be worth providing documentation to build Dexed on other architectures besides just x86. I opened an issue instead of making a pull request, though, because I have never encountered Juce before and have no idea what the most appropriate way to streamline the build process here would be. This is a solution that works, but it compiles a huge amount of extra code that isn't really needed, so it would be great if there were a way to avoid having to completely rebuild Juce and Projucer. 

At the very least, my hope is that this issue will be found by web searches for this problem when people who are relatively new to Linux try to build Dexed on their Raspberry Pi, just to us something to work with, but I do think that it would be really helpful and worthwhile for someone familiar with this build system to come up with a cleaner solution.

items.title: Can't send patches/cartridges in dexed, but can in Sysex Librarian
items.body:
Hi all,

I am new to dexed, and it is awesome!

I recently got a Korg OpSix FM synth, and I have seen videos of folks sending DX7 cartridges to it via Sysex over midi with Dexed. I tried yesterday, and I just couldn't get it to work. I'm wondering if anyone has any ideas.

I'm running a MacBook Air with Mojave.
The OpSix USB was set as the MIDI output for Dexed.
When I send the cartridge (as I saw in a video), it never registers on the OpSix.
However, when I use Sysex Librarian, it works no problem. I must be doing something wrong in dexed, and I hope someone maybe has a suggestion. I can certainly continue to transfer carts with Sysex Librarian, but if possible I would love to use dexed for both auditioning patches *and* sending them.

Thanks for any thoughs.

Cheers,
Zach

items.title: Pretty names for VST3 parameters ?
items.body:
Hello,
I am trying to make Dexed work correctly in my VST3 host, [ossia score](https://ossia.io).

I have this code called when I move a controller in the Dexed UI: 

```C++
void Model::addControlFromEditor(
    Steinberg::Vst::ParamID id,
    Steinberg::Vst::ParamValue valueNormalized)
{
  Steinberg::Vst::ParameterInfo p;
  if(fx.controller->getParameterInfo(paramIdToIndex(id), p) == Steinberg::kResultOk)
  {
    qDebug() 
     << QString::fromUtf16(p.title)
     << QString::fromUtf16(p.shortTitle) 
     << QString::fromUtf16(p.units);
  }
}
```
 
which prints me for most parameters (except Output FEEDBACK, ALGORITHM, LFO SPEED and a couple ones)
```
"MIDI CC 12|12" "" "" 
```
(with the CC changing depending on the parameter).

Do you have any idea of how I could get the proper parameter names as with the VST2 version instead of these MIDI CC things ? Other VST3 plug-ins I tried (Vital, the Steinberg examples) seem to give me correct names but I guess there's some IBlablaHandler that I haven't implemented... thanks !

items.title: Remove memcpy overwriting normalised parameters
items.body: The memcpy appeared to be overwriting the previously normalised parameters unpacked in the for loop above it. This pull request removes the memcpy under the assumption that the intended behaviour was to normalise the values instead of copying them straight into the unpacked program.

items.title: LFO speed range twice too small
items.body:
A quote from the original DX7 manual:
> "The LFO output can be varied in "speed" over a range from under 1 Hz to about 50 Hz"

According to my own measurements it goes to just below 48 Hz.
But now I measured Dexed output and it seems all LFO speed frequencies are a factor 2 too slow! The upper limit when LFS=99 that I measured using Dexed was 23.81 Hz. I have not checked the sourcecode (yet).

If Dexed wants to be as close as possible to a real DX7 I think this is a bug that should not be difficult to fix?
